text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

This IRM supersedes IRM 9.5.2 dated June 24, 2014. This IRM also incorporates procedure(s) implemented by the Director, Operations Policy and Support, guidance memorandum dated May 1, 2015, [Subject: “Field Office Guidance - Notice of Department of Justice Referral Memorandum”].
Criminal Investigation (CI)
Table of Contents
Authority For Requesting Grand Jury Investigations

) Special agents are authorized to assist the attorney for the government in ducting investigations, preparing for indictment and trial, and obtaining evidence relative to sentencing in matters involving potential violations of
, Title
, and/or Title

of the United States Code committed in tion of tax, bank secrecy, or money laundering statutes. An attorney for the government or Strike Force Attorney may request special agents to assist such investigations by a Federal grand jury, or to make presentations to a Federal grand jury. Also, the IRS or an attorney for the government may a request for a grand jury investigation. (

) The IRS may request the use of a grand jury either before, during, or after conducting an administrative investigation. A grand jury may normally be Of Grand Jury requested whenever: a. Using a grand jury would be more efficient, e.g., the administrative process cannot develop the relevant facts within a reasonable period time. b. An investigation has proceeded as far as the administrative process allows, but prosecution potential would be strengthened by the grand process. (

) An attorney for the government, such as an Assistant United States (AUSA), may ask for Criminal Investigation’s (CI) assistance in an ongoing proposed grand jury investigation whenever the information available to attorney indicates possible commission of crimes under the jurisdiction of IRS. (
) The following procedures should be used for grand jury requests. To Jury Requests (
) In both IRS initiated requests and requests initiated by an attorney for the ernment, the special agent must prepare Form
, Request for Grand Jury Requests Investigation. Criminal Tax (CT) Counsel reviews the Form
and the Potential Tax companying exhibits and prepares a Criminal Evaluation Memorandum Tax Related to the Special Agent in Charge (SAC) recommending action. Form
be signed by the SAC. For sensitive investigations, as defined in IRM Investigation Initiation, the written concurrence of the Chief, Criminal tion must be obtained. (
) If this request contains any information governed by the grand jury secrecy provisions, the special agent must stamp or print on the top right hand of Form
the phrase: “Caution: This document contains secret grand information.” The special agent will also place a cover sheet over the which states: “This report contains secret grand jury information.” (

) Internal Revenue Service initiated requests should include: a. Identification of the probable criminal matters, including contemplated Initiated charges, tax returns at issue, identification of individuals involved, and dications of wrongdoing which support the contemplated charges. b. Identification of potential witnesses, and recommendations as to the monial and documentary evidence to be sought before the grand jury. No.

and the ac- companying exhibits and prepares a Criminal Evaluation Memorandum to the Special Agent in Charge (SAC) recommending action. Form

the phrase: “Caution: This document contains secret grand information.” The special agent will also place a cover sheet over the which states: “This report contains secret grand jury information.” (

) Internal Revenue Service initiated requests should include: a. Identification of the probable criminal matters, including contemplated charges, tax returns at issue, identification of individuals involved, and dications of wrongdoing which support the contemplated charges. b. Identification of potential witnesses, and recommendations as to the monial and documentary evidence to be sought before the grand jury.

Investigative c. A summary of the investigation to date, including all investigative steps taken, all evidence developed (including witnesses contacted and their testimony), and all summonses issued but not yet complied with the status of summons enforcement activities). d. A summary of any existing or prospective civil actions against the subject(s). e. The reason(s) why a grand jury investigation is being requested (e.g., need for quick action rather than the administrative process; the need subpoenas rather than administrative summonses; any other relevant factors). f. The importance of the anticipated prosecution(s) to compliance. (
) Completed requests and supporting documents will be forwarded as in subsection
below. (

) Government attorney initiated requests for grand jury assistance should be submitted in writing to the SAC and include: a. name and taxpayer identification number (TIN) of the subject(s) b. names of other law enforcement agencies involved in the investigation c. any non-tax violations d. years involved e. probable tax violations (
) If the request includes grand jury information, it should specifically authorize the disclosure of grand jury material to IRS personnel in accordance with USCS Fed Rules Crim Proc R

(e). The authorization should include disclo- sure of information necessary to evaluate the request. The existence of jury information automatically qualifies the requests as a grand jury request. (See subsection

) The request should include a statement indicating if there is an “ongoing” grand jury investigation. Note: In order to meet the criteria for a direct referral of a grand jury request to attorney for the government, subpoenas must have been served and/or some evidence must have been presented to the grand jury. , Request for Grand Jury Investigation. (

and the accompanying documents/exhibits and prepares a CEM to the SAC recommending action. (

) If the SAC believes that CI should not participate in the grand jury tion, the SAC will advise the attorney for the government in writing, stating reasons for not participating, and will return all grand jury materials together with a list of all IRS personnel who had access to these materials. All grand jury requests involving potential tax and/or tax related violations be approved by the supervisory special agent (SSA) and reviewed by CT Counsel. Criminal Tax Counsel prepares a CEM to the SAC recommending action. The grand jury request must then be approved by the SAC. If the jury request relates to a sensitive investigation, as defined in IRM
, tigation Initiation, the written concurrence of the Chief, Criminal Investigation must be obtained. Time allotted for the review of grand jury requests that are IRS initiated: a. CT Counsel -

workdays of receipt b. Director, Field Operations (when applicable) - five workdays of receipt Time allotted for the review of grand jury requests that are government attorney initiated: a. ) initiated grand jury requests involving potential tax and/or tax related violations, will be routed the SAC to the DOJ, Tax Division. ) In order to expand an existing tax and/or tax related grand jury investigation to include additional subject(s), tax period(s) or type(s) of tax, the attorney for the government must obtain DOJ, Tax Division approval. (
) Department of Justice, Tax Division, Directive
permits the attorney for the government to expand an existing non-tax grand jury to include Title
Department of Justice, Tax Division, Directive 86–59 permits the attorney for the government to expand an existing non-tax grand jury to include Title 26

offenses, (except where the grand jury proceedings involve a multi- jurisdictional investigation or involve targets considered to have national prominence, such as public officials, political candidates, members of the judiciary, religious or labor leaders, news media representatives, and major corporations and/or their officers). In order to meet the criteria for a direct referral of a grand jury request to the attorney for the government, must have been served and/or some evidence must have been presented the grand jury. (
) Pursuant to Directive

, the attorney for the government may designate the subject(s), scope of the inquiry, and the tax period(s) to be investigated. However, the approval of the DOJ, Tax Division, must be obtained before issuing of an information or seeking the return of an indictment on tax and related matters. (
) An attorney for the government seeking an expansion of either an existing tax related or non-tax grand jury investigation should make a request in to the SAC. (See subsection
) The SAC will place the written request from the attorney for the government the administrative file and route a copy to a SSA for assignment to a agent. (
) The special agent will then update Criminal Investigation Management tion System (CIMIS) and prepare a Form
, Request for Grand Jury Investigation, for the expansion request. In lieu of preparing the Form

, the expansion request can be transmitted with a special agent’s report. Note: If the expansion request involves subjects in other field offices, the SAC, through the Director(s), Field Operations, must secure the concurrence of appropriate SAC(s). (
) Under exigent circumstances, expansion requests may be approved by Tax Division by telephone. However, written requests must already have approved by the SAC before this procedure can be used. (

) Within five workdays of a telephonic approval, the SAC will forward the request to the approving DOJ, Tax Division official, together with the memorandum containing an explanation of the exigent circumstances which warranted the telephonic procedure.

The USCS Fed Rules Crim Proc R
(e) prohibits the disclosure of grand jury material or information, except as specifically authorized in subparagraph (
). The procedures listed in this section are designed to ensure that this Rule is not violated.
who have access to the grand jury information”. The list will include the CI; Deputy Chief, CI; and Director, Operations Policy and Support. (

) Thereafter, all persons who have access to the grand jury information, including telephonic access, must be made aware of the grand jury secrecy rules and must have their names added to the Grand Jury Access List. (

) The employees listed on the initial Grand Jury Access List need not sign list in order to have access to grand jury information. The SAC and Field Operations will ensure that all employees under their control who access to grand jury information are familiar with grand jury secrecy rules. (

) The SSA may delegate the responsibility of maintaining the Grand Jury List to a special agent assigned to the grand jury investigation, but must ensure that the list is maintained timely and accurately. The SSA will the list to the attorney for the government. (
) Form

, Grand Jury Access List (Collateral), will be included with all jury collateral requests that contain or will result in grand jury information. SSA in the field office that initiates the grand jury collateral request may delegate the responsibility of issuing and maintaining Forms
to a agent assigned to the grand jury investigation, but must ensure that the personnel listed on each Form

are added to the Grand Jury Access The SAC of the field office that receives a grand jury collateral request will ensure that all personnel in the field office having access to the grand jury formation will sign Form
The SAC may delegate this responsibility to SSA. (

) When the Treasury Inspector General For Tax Administration (TIGTA) request involving a matter investigated by a grand jury, CI will immediately Jury allow them to review all information obtained prior to the grand jury referral all information obtained during the investigation which are not matters For occurring before the grand jury. contains listings of items are generally classified as grand jury materials and non-grand jury Criminal Investigation may consult CT Counsel if there is a question about classifying the information. (

(e). Criminal Investigation will describe in general terms the nature of the items (e.g., a transcript of testimony).
who have access to the grand jury information”. The list will include the Chief, CI; Deputy Chief, CI; and Director, Operations Policy and Support.

The employees listed on the initial Grand Jury Access List need not sign the list in order to have access to grand jury information. The SAC and Director, Field Operations will ensure that all employees under their control who have access to grand jury information are familiar with grand jury secrecy rules.

When the Treasury Inspector General For Tax Administration (TIGTA) makes a request involving a matter investigated by a grand jury, CI will immediately allow them to review all information obtained prior to the grand jury referral and all information obtained during the investigation which are not matters occurring before the grand jury. Exhibit

contains listings of items that are generally classified as grand jury materials and non-grand jury materials. Criminal Investigation may consult CT Counsel if there is a question about classifying the information. Criminal Investigation will advise TIGTA if full disclosure cannot be made of all items in the file because certain items fall within the scope of Rule
(e). Criminal Investigation will describe in general terms the nature of the items
) Grand jury information may not be used for civil purposes unless the obtains the information independently of the grand jury or through a Jury order. (

) To prevent doubt about the origins of information available for civil use, SSA should ensure the segregation of information prior to the receipt of grand jury information and have such material clearly marked as jury. After the grand jury investigation begins, any information obtained pendently of the grand jury should be kept separate and clearly an independent source. The Grand Jury Guidelines included in Exhibit may be used in the classification of information. (

) Field personnel should consult CT Counsel when questions arise in the gation process. The ultimate decision, however, to release evidence during a grand jury investigation falls within the purview of the attorney government. Information deemed to be non-grand jury in nature should released unless the responsible DOJ attorney reviews the material and authorize the release. The government attorney’s approval should be mented in the respective case file. (
) In general, IRS personnel who have received grand jury information the secrecy provisions of Rule
(e) will exclude themselves from in non-grand jury matters concerning the individuals, entities, and matter of the grand jury information. (
) The SAC and other CI managers may not use grand jury information to a non-grand jury investigation. (
) While assisting the attorney for the government, neither special agents revenue agents may solicit or seek information for other than criminal purposes. Jury (
) Requirements for the security of grand jury information are set forth in
, Physical Security Program. (
) Some of the unique aspects to CI techniques peculiar to grand jury tions are listed in the following subsections. (
) Internal Revenue Manual
Grand jury information may not be used for civil purposes unless the IRS obtains the information independently of the grand jury or through a Rule
While assisting the attorney for the government, neither special agents nor revenue agents may solicit or seek information for other than criminal
Some of the unique aspects to CI techniques peculiar to grand jury tions are listed in the following subsections.
Investigative (

) A subpoena is a writ issued by the authority of the court ordering an individual to appear at a specified date, time, and place to testify or to give evidence, or both, in a matter pending before the court. Subpoena Duces Tecum is a command to a witness to testify and to produce at a trial, a deposition, or a hearing, documents or papers in his possession that are pertinent to the of a pending case. (See USCS Fed Rules Crim Proc R
and R
) IRS employees may not use Form
, Summons, under any circumstances in grand jury investigations. However, they may issue Form
, Document Receipt, when securing documents pursuant to a grand jury subpoena. (
) A subpoena may be issued for grand jury investigative purposes and trial pro- ceedings. (

) At the request of a government attorney, a special agent may assist with the preparation and service of subpoenas for witness testimony and with the pro- duction of books, papers, documents, or objects. The following suggestions may aid the special agent in assisting the attorney for the government: a. Review the subpoena for accuracy and content. b. Prepare and serve the subpoena as promptly as possible. c. Complete the Return of Service section, the Statement of Service Fees section, and the Declaration of Service section of the subpoena. d. Inform the government attorney of any circumstances which may affect timely appearance of a witness, the production of documentary evidence or any difficulty in locating or serving a witness. e. Maintain a listing of all subpoenas requested, the date each was received, the date each was served, and the date each was returned to the court. f. Keep a log of the records provided by the witness and returned by that witness to the grand jury. Note any records which were requested by the subpoena but not provided. Suggest to add a request in the subpoena the witness provide a letter referencing any documents requested by the subpoena but not provided. g. Keep a log of the records provided by the witness and turned over to the special agent in lieu of the witness’ grand jury appearance. Note any records which were requested but not provided. Suggest to add a request in the subpoena that the witness provide a letter referencing any documents requested by the subpoena but not provided. h. Keep a log of the records in (g) above that are presented to the grand by the special agent. i. Prepare an inventory of records received to associate with the ing subpoena. (

) Witnesses may be requested to submit to an interview by a special agent and/or an the attorney for the government, in advance of testifying before a grand jury or a court, for purposes of reviewing their testimony and ascertain- ing whether the necessary documentary evidence is available. Witnesses should be given the maximum possible notice prior to their appearance so that the necessary travel accommodations can be arranged. The attorney for the government office will provide guidance with respect to travel arrangements. (

) The attorney for the government office will provide guidance and direction relating to individuals who may or may not be served with a subpoena without prior approval by the attorney for the government or DOJ. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

Service of a subpoena to a third-party recordkeeper can be directed to the Custodian of Records for the business or corporation.
In the United States: A subpoena directed to a witness for attendance at a court proceeding may be served at any place within the United States.

) The following administrative procedures are peculiar to grand jury investiga- tions. To Jury

the IRS to make a payment to or on behalf of an informant, the special agent should prepare Form 8561, Request for Confidential Funds. The request should state that it contains grand jury information. The names of the approving officials should be added to the Grand Jury Access List.

For a collateral request that contains or will result in grand jury information, SSA or a special agent assigned to the grand jury investigation will obtain approval from the attorney for the government. ) When a case has been referred for a grand jury investigation, CI will original tax returns and will establish transaction code (TC)
or TC

Tax Returns controls on all tax periods under grand jury investigation. The affected operating division(s) will transfer to CI all returns and administrative files periods under grand jury investigation. (

) If returns for periods under grand jury investigation are located in other offices, the other operating division with the returns will transfer the together with all administrative files, to CI in the field offices where the jury is impaneled. The affected operating division will continue to control returns for any types of taxes and for any periods not being investigated grand jury. (
) Transaction code
will be placed on all individuals and entities input Criminal Investigations Management Information System (CIMIS) as Identities. (

) If the tax returns under investigation were under the control of another operating division at the time CI’s participation in the grand jury was autho- for Civil rized, the other operating division which transferred the returns to CI is Limitations responsible for the civil statute of limitations. (
) If there has been no civil involvement before the start of a grand jury tion and a Rule
(e) order has not been obtained, CI is not responsible for civil statute of limitations. (

) The SAC will discuss any proposed civil action with the attorney for the ernment. The attorney for the government will provide the SAC in writing any reasons why a proposed civil action may jeopardize the criminal tion. (
) The SAC will weigh the proposed civil action against the criminal and make a recommendation to the operating division Territory Manager without disclosing any grand jury information. (
) In the event that the other operating division does not agree to suspend activity, the procedures contained in P-

In determining if something is a “matter occurring before the grand jury”, courts have looked at factors including:
when the evidence was obtained
whether the evidence was obtained independent of the grand jury
whether the grand jury process was used to obtain the evidence
whether the evidence was ever presented to the grand jury
whether the evidence was obtained as the result of a lead, and if so, did the lead constitute a grand matter
whether the evidence was created specifically for the grand jury
what type of evidence is at issue
whether the disclosure would reveal what transpired before the grand jury
whether the evidence has been disclosed in open court
transcripts of grand jury testimony
witness identification information
target identification data
memorandums and other written records of meetings with subjects or witnesses wherein the individual was advised of existence of grand jury investigation
government memorandums, summaries, letters, analysis, etc., that refer to grand jury testimony or poenaed documents
Items generally not constituting a “matter occurring before the grand jury” and not protected by Rule 6(e) include:
evidence gathered prior to a grand jury referral, which has been clearly identified and segregated, even if subsequently presented to a grand jury

evidence obtained during the course of a grand jury investigation, without use of the grand jury process and not presented to the grand jury, and without any disclosure as to the existence of a grand jury
public domain information, including government agency records, court pleadings, discovery requests and responses, filed (non-sealed) search warrant affidavits, indictments, and plea agreements
Exhibit 9.5.2-1 (Cont. 1) (11-05-2004) Grand Jury Guidelines
In-court testimony and exhibits related thereto, which are not under seal, even if such information was previously presented to the grand jury
summaries and analyses of evidence prepared prior to the referral to the grand jury
